title: Luffy Will Master Advanced Conqueror's Haki
theoryText: Given that Rayleigh emphasized Conqueror's Haki can only be strengthened through personal growth rather than training, fans theorized that Luffy's two-year training would focus not just on physical abilities but on maturing as a person and leader. The theory suggests that by the end of training, Luffy would develop advanced applications of Conqueror's Haki beyond just knocking out weak-willed opponents.
author: One Piece Fan Community
communityVerdict: This theory was eventually confirmed as Luffy developed advanced applications of Conqueror's Haki in later arcs.

title: The 500 Beasts Represent Different Haki Training Levels
theoryText: Some fans theorized that the 500 beasts on Rusukaina, all stronger than Luffy at the start, were intentionally chosen by Rayleigh as progressive training challenges. The theory suggests each beast might require different applications of Haki to defeat, with the weakest beasts testing basic Observation and Armament Haki, while the strongest would require mastery of all three types or advanced techniques.
author: One Piece Fan Community
communityVerdict: While never explicitly confirmed, the manga/anime showed Luffy eventually becoming 'boss of the island' suggesting he did defeat or befriend the beasts through his training.

title: Rayleigh's Training Methods Mirror Roger's Journey
theoryText: Fans theorized that Rayleigh's training approach with Luffy would parallel how Gol D. Roger trained or developed his crew. Since Rayleigh was Roger's first mate, his knowledge of what it takes to conquer the Grand Line and reach Laugh Tale would inform his training curriculum. This theory suggests that Rayleigh is essentially creating the next Pirate King using lessons learned from his time with Roger.
author: One Piece Fan Community
communityVerdict: Later revelations about Roger's journey and abilities suggest Rayleigh was indeed passing on knowledge from the Roger Pirates era, though specific training methods were not directly shown to mirror Roger's experience.

title: The Special Ending Card Signals a New Era of One Piece
theoryText: The unique 'Go To New World' ending card instead of the usual 'To Be Continued' sparked theories that the post-timeskip One Piece would be fundamentally different in tone, pacing, and scale. Fans speculated this wasn't just a physical journey to a new sea, but a narrative shift to more mature themes, higher stakes, and greater focus on the overarching mysteries of the One Piece world.
author: One Piece Fan Community
communityVerdict: This theory was largely confirmed as the post-timeskip era did feature more mature themes, deeper world-building, political intrigue, and revelations about the Void Century and ancient history.
